title: Tuesday, 12th September, 2017

11:01 am

PM11:02am

PM11:05am

American society + drugs = well...

PM11:05am

11:06 am
BE11:06am

It's a really interesting area. One of the areas I ended up discussing in the pub the other day is the difficulty of diagnosing pain, which is the loophole through which a lot of opioids drop.

BE11:06am

As in .....

BE11:07am

Many pain experts say the drugs should only be used in terminally ill people or those suffering from acute episodes of pain, but drugmakers tried to market the pills to patients with chronic conditions like bad backs or necks, the lawsuit alleges. 

It points to advertising produced by Endo, which included images of people working “physically demanding jobs” such as construction site employees and chefs, the inference being that the company’s Opana ER drug was suitable for those with long-term pain complaints. 

11:07 am
BE11:08am

From there we get into the two dozen or so pain scales in use .... But, yes, this is probably outside our remit.

Redrow PLC (RDW:LSE): Last: 580.50, down 52 (-8.22%), High: 588.00, Low: 569.00, Volume: 3.20m
BE11:13am

Steve Morgan slotting.

BE11:14am

Founder and now Executive Chairman, selling 7% (25.9m shares).

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Still holds on to 33%, though the question is whether he's now
a long-term holder of the rest.

BE11:15am

Or whether a third of Redrow is now an overhang any time it moves near 600p-ish.

BE11:16am

Statement runs that he "remains fully committed to the business and confident in the outlook" and that "proceeds will be used to diversify the seller’s investment portfolio."

11:16 am
BE11:16am

As you'd expect.

BE11:17am

UBS is not convinced.

BE11:17am

Mr. Morgan founded Redrow in 1974 at the age of 21, having grown the business up until it became a listed company in 1994, and before he decided to step down as Chairman in 2000. After a period of significant turbulence in 2008 (incl. a 60% impairment on land), he returned to Redrow in 2009, having rebuilt his stake. He then changed the business strategy, refocused on more prudent land buying, and raised £150m in a rights issue in 2009 and a further £80m in 2012 to pursue its growth plans with a particular focus on the London market. Redrow has had a major recovery since 2009, with legal completions up by 156% from 2,113 units to 5,416 in FY17, PBT (pre- ex) from -£44m to £315m, EPS (pre-ex) from -14.7p to 70.2p, and TSR of c400%.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

We believe this announcement could raise the question on whether Mr. Morgan will ultimately sell his entire stake in the company, and whether Redrow will be able to continue to grow successfully without Mr. Morgan's leadership. However, we highlight the market is now supported by (1) low interest rates; (2) structural undersupply; (3) supportive land market with limited competition allowing for attractive returns; (4) Government support in the form of Help-to-Buy and planning reform. Furthermore, Redrow has for the 2nd time this year (Sep-17), upgraded its mid-term targets, with PBT'20E set at £430m, c15% above UBSe/consensus estimates at the time.

BE11:19am

Ashtead Group PLC (AHT:LSE): Last: 1,818, up 134 (+7.96%), High: 1,828, Low: 1,722, Volume: 1.28m
11:26 am
BE11:27am

Hurricanes are proving good for business this year.

BE11:27am

You'll remember that they were at best neutral for business back in 2015, but I guess we're getting the right type of hurricanes now.

BE11:28am

........ so, Q1 starts well.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

MOST can summarise.

BE11:29am

Key points: Group revenue and profit: Q1 total revenue of £880m, +5% ahead vs. MSe of £838m and 2.1% ahead of cons £862m. Rental revenue for Q1 of £829m was +4.9% above MSe of £790m, which represents growth of +17% at constant FX. Group EBITDA of £431.1m and adjusted PBT of £238.5m compares to MSe of £418m and £222m. Q118 EPS was 31.5p vs. MSe 29.27p.

BE11:29am

Sunbelt: Rental only revenue for Q1 of $745m was +4.8% above MSe of $711m and total revenue of $983m was +3.9% above MSe of $946m. EBITDA of $503m was +2.3% higher than MSe of $492m.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

A-Plant: Rental only revenue of £91m was +6.8% above MSe of £85m, Total revenue of £119m was +12.7% above MSe £106m. EBITDA of £44.7m was +10.2% above MSe of £40.6m.

BE11:29am

Capex: Q1 gross capex was at £377m and £354m net of disposals with the gross value of the fleet reaching £6.2bn vs. MSe of £380m gross capex (£360.5m Rental capex) and £5.99bn gross fleet value.

BE11:30am

Outlook: No specific guidance was given; management highlight both businesses are performing well with positive momentum. It is too early to attempt to quantify the impact of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma, but management expect an increase in demand for fleet. The board "looks to the medium term with confidence".

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Hurricane guidance came mostly on the conference call

BE11:30am

As per Barclays.

BE11:31am

Hurricanes: The immediate incremental demand as a result of a hurricane will come in AHT’s higher-returns specialty business – this is likely to cause some short-term volatility in yield in 2Q. Longer-term, Ashtead expect demand for equipment to increase (as rebuild happens) while supply of equipment has decreased (AHT lost $30m of fleet in Texas and assuming its experience is representative of the industry, this implies c$300m of fleet based on AHT’s 10% market share in Texas – small local players have no scope to replace quickly with equipment from other locations, and less ability than AHT to pull capital equipment orders forward) – this has implications for volume growth and rates in two of AHT’s key markets over the next couple of years.

11:31 am
PM11:31am

(back)

BE11:31am

(@HaydnP: Paul McCartney and Brian Eno.)

BE11:32am

JP Morgan, also from the conference call.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Hurricane season impact. All the commentary on the likely impact was caveated with the reality that assessing the impact at this stage is very difficult. Management will update on the expected impact of the hurricanes with the Q2’18 results. What is clear is that there will be an impact in the Q2 but more importantly over a number of years with a major rebuild programme required. Demand is not the only factor, the impact on supply of equipment and lost fleet is also important as a driver. Rates are set to improve as a result of both additional demand and the lower supply of equipment. Additionally there are impacts outside of just immediate increased demand. The benefit Ashtead has is the scale and national footprint. The group has a storm team in Charlotte that monitors the national fleet, where there is spare fleet this fleet can be shipped to the areas that need it such as in Texas and Florida currently. This access to $7bn of fleet is a huge differentiator when compared to local players (who will likely have been hit themselves in terms of fleet).
Additionally, the group has agreements with suppliers to call off additional equipment, on top of the usual weekly deliveries providing access to more equipment as required. Equipment that was planned to go to other regions as normal course of business can be relocated to impacted areas. Events like this can also provide a longer-term benefit as customers remember who helped them when they needed it and this can help longer-term market share gains. Management was careful to use Sandy as a reference point as market share in the impacted areas was low at the time so this was just an outright win providing an opportunity to enter a market.
Hurricane Katrina may be a better reference point, however the market was very strong as that time so isolating the Katrina impact is difficult. It is worth outlining that United Rentals is similarly well positioned to benefit from the impacts outlined.

BE11:33am

..... so, we're getting a small rally among the US rebuild stocks, of which there aren't many.

I'd hate do do a geospacial analysis on Greggs customers.

PM11:39am

UBS Evidence Lab: Geospatial analysis provides support to store number upside

PM11:40am

We see significant store roll-out potential beyond the formal Greggs management target supported by our UBS Evidence Lab Geospatial analysis. Our analysis indicates the potential for a store number in excess of 2,500 (vs. 1,768 in FY16 and Greggs target of 'substantially more than 2,000 shops') with Greggs well positioned given lower cannibalisation and competitor incidence rates than Costa Coffee, a competitor still delivering good growth with a store base

25% larger than Greggs, indicating an opportunity to increase density along with its strategy to diversify locations to include more work and travel locations. With this note we reiterate our Buy rating, and increase our net store opening run-rate to 80-90 in 2018-21E (vs. 60 previously), and forecast over 2,200 stores by FY21.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

.............. fascinating.

PM11:40am

Sorry for the formatting

PM11:40am

UBS Evidence Lab geospatial analysis allows us to compare the current store footprint for Greggs versus the largest coffee chains and convenience store competitors, looking at data points such as cannibalisation, competitor density, and geographical and demographic features of the store estate. Key conclusions include; (1) Lower levels of same brand cannibalisation for Greggs than Costa Coffee means potential support for increasing store density; (2) Regional share of sites shows Greggs is underpenetrated in areas such as the South West, supportive of growth strategy outlined; and (3) current store numbers for key competitors Costa Coffee and Subway already greater than 25% ahead, with clear growth ambitions highlighting the opportunity in this market for Greggs.

11:40 am
PM11:41am

Self-help initiatives key to the ongoing growth story
We continue to believe that Greggs offers an attractive story despite UK consumer uncertainty, in particular in coffee which remains a meaningful opportunity as discussed in our March 2017 note here, with potential to increased penetration given its competitive price point. In addition, ongoing supply chain investment means there are defined cost savings planned out to 2020, which will be supportive to margins.

SSP Group PLC (SSPG:LSE): Last: 514.02, down 14.98 (-2.83%), High: 519.00, Low: 507.00, Volume: 661.82k
BE11:43am

Big sector note, mostly post the Greene King warning.

BE11:44am

SSP's expensive.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

That's the conclusion.

BE11:44am

We like SSP’s business and continue to see long term potential from taking share in North America and growing the business in developing markets but the current multiple (29.5x FY17E PE) does not allow for any missteps. We increase our forecasts c2% (FX) and our target price to 550p (from 530p).

BE11:45am

Slowing UK consumer and geo-political events present near term risks. We expect FY17 to have closed out strongly with group LFL of 3% (9 months +3.2%). We expect 3% LFL growth in FY18 driven by ongoing optimism about global economic growth and air capacity expansion in Europe and US. Nevertheless downside risks exist from slowing UK consumer confidence and geopolitical events. Up to now we felt those risks were outweighed by the upside potential from strong execution. With the shares now trading at almost 28x PE (FY17E) we struggle to see upside and downgrade to Neutral.

11:46 am

PM11:47am

PM11:48am

The August print surprised to the upside. Headline CPIH inflation came in stronger (2.7%) than we had expected (2.6%) and in line with consensus. In the CPI space, the upward surprise compared to our forecast was larger. Headline CPI rose by 0.3pp to 2.9% from 2.6% (Barclays: 2.7%, consensus: 2.8%) mainly supported by core inflation printing 2.7% (Barclays and consensus: 2.5%) from 2.4% previously. RPI rose to 3.9% y/y (index: 274.7); we and consensus had forecast a 3.7% y/y print.

11:48 am
PM11:48am

That's a Barc snap

PM11:48am

UK Economics Research
Threads of higher inflation

CPIH RPI
Actual: 2.7% y/y Actual: 3.9% y/y; Index: 274.7
Barclays: 2.6% y/y Barclays: 3.7% y/y; Index: 274.3
Consensus: 2.7% y/y Consensus: 3.7% y/y; Index: 274.3

The August print surprised to the upside. Headline CPIH inflation came in stronger (2.7%) than we had expected (2.6%) and in line with consensus. In the CPI space, the upward surprise compared to our forecast was larger. Headline CPI rose by 0.3pp to 2.9% from 2.6% (Barclays: 2.7%, consensus: 2.8%) mainly supported by core inflation printing 2.7% (Barclays and consensus: 2.5%) from 2.4% previously. RPI rose to 3.9% y/y (index: 274.7); we and consensus had forecast a 3.7% y/y print.

CPIH and RPI in greater detail (Figures 1 and 2). The main positive core contribution to the CPIH y/y rate change came from clothing & footwear prices (+0.08). Jumping by 2.4% m/m, the August rise was larger than in the same month of 2016 (+1.0%); according to the ONS, the unexpected rise may have been influenced by a different proportion of items on sales this year compared to last. Weather conditions have led brands to front-run winter collections and end summer sales early, pushing up the average prices of items sold in August relative to last year. First indications (strong fashion sales numbers by John Lewis and lower markdowns by Primark) are that this is also likely to be the case in September. Also within core goods, furniture, household equipment & routine maintenance provided support albeit to a much lesser extent (+0.02). There were also notable developments at services level where the support was broad based. Communication, recreation & culture and hotels, cafes & restaurants prices all contributed positively for 0.11pp in total; air fares subtracted 0.04pp. At the non-core level, the bulk of the support was from cane with fuel and lubricants, which rose to 5.1% y/y from 2.0% in July, which was slightly tempered by weak food and drink (-0.05pp).

RPI saw a positive base effect from last year’s BoE rate cut dropping out of the y/y mortgage interest rate payment comparison. However, this will likely temporarily reverse in September owing to erratic behavior in this component last year stemming from erroneous effective interest rate assumptions. Otherwise, petrol prices have a higher weight in RPI than CPIH and use a point estimate rather than a whole month average (which CPIH uses), so the upside news here was more pronounced.

Today’s print suggests upside risks to our projected inflation profile for this year and next. Cheapening currency and rising oil prices are the most obvious factors to blame. However we believe it is very difficult to calibrate the magnitude of the risk beyond the mechanical impact that potentially more inflationary than currently penciled in oil and FX assumptions may have on headline inflation through the energy components. Markets have quickly made up their minds on today’s print and an August 2018 hike is now fully priced in again while nothing was expected before 2019.

BE11:52am

We are cautious on European hotels. We downgrade Whitbread to Sell (from Buy) forecasting just a 5.5% EBIT CAGR to FY21, while our Accor Buy is based on its planned propco spin-off (we expect €4.6b cash, €2b cash return). On WTB, our proprietary analysis, with the Research Innovation Lab, of all Costa, Caffe Nero, Starbucks and Greggs shops in the UK leads us to forecast just c.4-5 years structural growth left in the branded UK coffee market. For Premier Inn, we forecast just 0.5%-2% RevPAR growth to FY21, causing margin compression. Conversely, international is only meaningful with significant investment, and associated risks. New 3,200p TP, -13% ETR.

BE11:54am

Damn scientific, this research lark. Totally not monkeys with pins.

PM11:55am

(grumpy - nope)

BE11:55am

Debunking the UK coffee market structural growth myth

Combined with our Innovation Lab, we have gathered and analysed data on the locations of all UK coffee shops for the Costa, Starbucks, Caffe Nero, and Greggs brands to consider the attractiveness of their site locations and whether there remains a structural growth opportunity in the branded UK coffee market. There are three interesting conclusions:
1. Based on our analysis of c.7,200 areas in England and Wales we believe that the market could comfortably support a total of 2,100 additional branded coffee shops. If we assume Costa’s market share is constant at 39%, this suggests Costa can open c.840 new stores or c.8 more years of growth (at its current rollout pace).
2. Considering Costa’s current estate, there are 472 coffee shops that have at least 4 other branded coffee shops (either another Costa or competitor) within 5 minutes’ walk. We believe many of these stores are likely facing very high levels of competition. Assuming Costa should look to rotate out of the majority of these stores when lease expiries come due, suggests only c.4-5 more years of structural growth.
3. The proliferation of alternative F&B providers who are improving their coffee offering (quick service restaurants, pubs, boutique coffee shops) could mean that the growth opportunity is less than we anticipate. The four brands we consider only make up c.26% of current UK coffee stores.

11:57 am

So they are calling the 'top' in eight years?

BE11:58am

BE11:59am

There was a request for JD Sports .......

JD Sports Fashion PLC (JD.:LSE): Last: 373.48, up 30.88 (+9.01%), High: 384.70, Low: 349.30, Volume: 3.99m
11:59 am
BE11:59am

A business I don't entirely understand, as every time I walk past one it seems to be empty.

BE12:00pm

Here's Peel Hunt (shop, I think) to explain why my experience is irrelevant to the investment case.

BE12:00pm

JD’s H1 performance is ahead of expectations and we are
upgrading. Including online sales (now nearly 14% of JD’s sales),
LFL remains the envy of most retailers, and profit delivery is
strong, with core margins flat despite various headwinds. Go
Outdoors has started well within the JD stable and we expect
further strong progress from each silo in H2. The shares have
been wrongly derated due to concerns from the US and slowing
athleisure momentum. Today’s numbers show that there is
plenty more running in the JD legs yet and we expect a strong
bounce back from 13x PE.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

£102.7m of PBT. We were forecasting around £93m, so a £100m+ result was a decent outcome against that number: it sets up a nice upgrade (essentially we are keeping our H2 forecast unchanged and just adding the £m beat to FY numbers). In-store LFL in the core UK JD business was 3% against an eye-wateringly tough comparative. In Europe, the LFL number was 7%, another fine effort given last year (Holland was the toughest market in this half, things were marginally more bearable in Germany). Both of these LFL numbers do not include online sales: they are now 13.7% of UK/Ireland sports fashion sales (up from 11.1%): had LFL been included online, it would have been 6% in the UK and 10% elsewhere. Both of which are striking numbers and on top of the material volume growth that we have seen in the last few years, it gives JD a very strong bargaining position with suppliers. The gross margin was down by just 30 bps in the JD fascia, a good effort given the headwinds, and the net margin was flat, despite the living wage being a factor again. All in all, it was a very strong showing from the core business and we expect continued in-store and online growth in H2, despite the tough comp again. Another 40 stores should open in the period and the pipeline of stores and good people to run them is very much intact.

BE12:01pm

Outdoors into profit. Blacks and Milletts’ performances improved, showing LFL growth and lower losses, and the contribution of Go Outdoors ensured that the silo was in the black. The business is starting to work as one: it’s early days but the buying teams and operations units have begun the discussion on how to move forward. It will be a while before the systems are conjoined, but JD’s increased scale in the space should bring about a stronger performance in time A £10m upgrade. It's not difficult to see how our upgrade could be too conservative. JD's trading form remains good across Europe , SUR Dutch losses will reduce in H2 and outdoors should make progress again. However, it's probably right to be a touch cautious given the wider economic background. We certainly don't think the trend towards athleisure is anywhere near played out, and the recent weakness means the shares can now be bought on an early teens multiple, which spells good value to us.

BE12:03pm

(@Lefevre: if you want fiction as a starting point, Common Prayer is a more entertaining read than Last Thing, which can be a bit heavy lifting at times.)

12:02 pm
undefined
PM12:03pm

Just out from Supergroup...

PM12:03pm

The founders of Superdry have launched an innovative long-term incentive scheme (the "Scheme") under which they will share their wealth with all 4,500 colleagues in the business worldwide. The move is part of the wider strategy to attract, retain and reward the best people, one of the cornerstones of the success of Superdry as a global lifestyle brand.

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

Here's the detail

PM12:03pm

At the conclusion of the scheme, Julian Dunkerton1 and James Holder1 will transfer into a fund 20 per cent of their gain from any increase in the Group's share price over a threshold of £18. The proceeds from this fund will be shared across the Superdry colleague base worldwide. Each £5 increase in the share price over the £18 threshold would see the founders putting £30m into the fund for all colleagues, including those who work part-time. At market close yesterday, shares in SuperGroup were trading at 1560p.
